harmonic functions

Let Ω={z∈C | Re⁡z>0 and Im⁡z>0}\Omega = \set{z \in \C \st \Re{z} > 0 \text{ and } \Im{z} > 0}Ω={z∈C∣Rez>0 and Imz>0}. Show that there exists a unique bounded harmonic function u ⁣:Ω→R\func{u}{\Omega}{\R}u:Ω→R such that for all x>0x > 0x>0 and y>0y > 0y>0,

lim⁡t→0u(x+it)=0andlim⁡t→0u(t+iy)=1.\lim_{t\to0} u\p{x + it} = 0 \quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{t\to0} u\p{t + iy} = 1.t→0lim​u(x+it)=0andt→0lim​u(t+iy)=1.
Solution.

First, we show uniqueness. If u,vu, vu,v are two such harmonic functions, then u−v=0u - v = 0u−v=0 on ∂Ω\partial\Omega∂Ω. Since u−vu - vu−v is bounded, we may apply the Phragmèn-Lindelöf method to see that the maximum principle still applies, so u−v≤0u - v \leq 0u−v≤0 on Ω\OmegaΩ. Applying the same argument to v−uv - uv−u, we see that u−v=0u - v = 0u−v=0 on Ω\OmegaΩ, so we have uniqueness.

For existence, first consider φ(z)=z2\phi\p{z} = z^2φ(z)=z2 and ψ(z)=z−iz+i\psi\p{z} = \frac{z - i}{z + i}ψ(z)=z+iz−i​. Observe that φ\phiφ maps Ω\OmegaΩ conformally to the upper half-plane H\HH, the negative real-axis to itself, and the positive imaginary axis to the negative real axis. Similarly, ψ\psiψ maps H\HH conformally to D\DD, maps the negative real axis to the arc (0,π)\p{0, \pi}(0,π), and maps the positive real axis to the arc (π,2π)\p{\pi, 2\pi}(π,2π). Thus, ψ∘φ\psi \circ \phiψ∘φ maps Ω\OmegaΩ conformally to D\DD, sending the positive real axis to the arc (π,2π)\p{\pi, 2\pi}(π,2π) and the positive imaginary axis to (0,π)\p{0, \pi}(0,π). On S1S^1S1, define

f(eiθ)={1if 0≤θ<π0if π≤θ<2π,f\p{e^{i\theta}} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } 0 \leq \theta < \pi \\ 0 & \text{if } \pi \leq \theta < 2\pi, \end{cases}f(eiθ)={10​if 0≤θ<πif π≤θ<2π,​

which is certainly in L1(S1)L^1\p{S^1}L1(S1). Hence, its Poisson integral vvv defines a harmonic function on D\DD such that v(z)→f(eiθ)v\p{z} \to f\p{e^{i\theta}}v(z)→f(eiθ) as z→eiθz \to e^{i\theta}z→eiθ at points of continuity of fff. In particular, v(z)→1v\p{z} \to 1v(z)→1 on 0<θ<π0 < \theta < \pi0<θ<π and v(z)→0v\p{z} \to 0v(z)→0 on π<θ<2π\pi < \theta < 2\piπ<θ<2π as z→eiθz \to e^{i\theta}z→eiθ. Thus,

u=v∘ψ∘φ ⁣:Ω→Ru = \func{v \circ \psi \circ \phi}{\Omega}{\R}u=v∘ψ∘φ:Ω→R

has the desired properties, since ψ∘φ\psi \circ \phiψ∘φ is continuous up to the boundary.
